response.answer_text: Define successfully. In fact, define invade. As in establish a toehold and actually operate in Russian territory? Probably IF a whole raft of factors align: the US has a shorter striking distance to Vladivostok than Russia’s western heartland does, so IF the US wanted to commit ungodly resources to taking a city in the bleak end of nowhere, including fighting it's way through half the Russian navy to take a city whose only value to the US would be to deny it to the Russians , strategically important in a larger conflict but otherwise not beneficial to the US, and subdue an impressive dug in garrison and occupy a good sized, likely less than cooperative city and untold miles and miles of howling frozen wilderness, if it was willing to spend a g@#$@++ fortune reinforcing and fortifying from inevitable counterattack, if it was able to pacify and reassure other powers like China that they didn't interfere, if the US was able to be reasonably assured that nukes would remain off the table. It is a tall order. The US has the raw power that such a selective invasion might be possible, but invading the home territory of a large country with a modern military is hardly a sure thing. I sure wouldn't want that job. Now, if you are asking if the US could conquer and invade the whole of Russia, then hell no. The Russian military could all go home and have beers and the US would still find it beyond its capabilities. Nor would the US attempt to. The logistical challenges to supporting an army capable of holding a territory like that against a hostile populace would be taxing for any country, and the US military isn't built to garrison a country so vast, and even if it was would represent a quagmire that could never be escaped. The US would find the costs crippling. And this is without the no doubt vigorous and violent resistance of the military. I cannot imagine a scenario where the US would want to try. Military actions are not conquer and subdue but rather to selectively deny resources and compel actions: we would need to know what the US would be trying to accomplish in this theoretical exercise. But I rank it slightly more plausible than a Russian takeover of Anchorage.

Realistically? No. Probably not. The U.S. military isn’t built to occupy, it’s built to defeat. If you want proof, look at Afghanistan and Iraq. I have little doubt the U.S. military, head-to-head against the Russian military, would make short work of them. The U.S. is vastly, VASTLY superior in almost every way than the Russians. But defeating their armed forces only gets you in the door, you still have to figure out how to control and ADMINISTER SERVICES, as well as maintain law and order, throughout the country. Undoubtedly, there would be otherwise fairly anti-Putin Russians who would be pretty pissed off at the Stars and Stripes flying high over their cities. How would Americans react if they saw the opposite here? So, the occupation force would have to be ENORMOUS considering how vast Russia is as a land mass. Millions of personnel and equipment. Trillions of dollars, too. After the U.S. beat the Russian military, cities would almost certainly be in ruins and would need to be rebuilt and be secured. Water and electricity would have to flow, and looting would need to be addressed quickly…because there would be a lot of it. Then we’d have to FIND and SECURE the Russian nuke sites to prevent them from falling into rebel or worse people’s hands. Nearly impossible to do. I can virtually guarantee the U.S. probably does not know where every Russian nuke is…kind of a huge problem for an occupation force. The logistics of an occupation of Russia would be unlike anything humans have ever attempted before. Mind-bogglingly difficult. Russia can’t even properly govern itself, you think WE could? An occupation of that country is more trouble than it is worth, honestly…and costly. But that’s all hypothetical anyway. The second actual combat operations started going badly for the Russians — like their fleets getting sunk by the U.S. Navy, their air force being neutralized, and their ground forces suffering under withering aerial and ground attack at all hours of the day — they’d just nuke us. Seriously. That’s how a war between the U.S. and Russia would end 100% of the time. We’d just nuke each other and be done with it.

As Napoleon Bonaparte and Adolf Hitler will tell you, no, no you cannot. First, Russia is HUGE, both in terms of landmass and in population. Its total landmass covers an area almost twice as large as the US covers, and its population is about half the size of the US. Its geography is also diverse, so imagine struggling your way through harsh Russian territory, all the while trying to dodge weather patterns (okay, the US is prepared for THAT part) and dealing with a very pissed-off country. It’s be like trying to attack the US…or China. That would suck. More importantly, however, Russia has the second most-powerful military in the world. It has over one million active personnel, the second largest air force, a huge navy, and over 7,300 nuclear weapons, all backed up by the 12th largest economy in the world (in terms of nominal GDP; if we’re looking at GDP PPP, it’s much, much larger). And these armed forces have been getting some good practice with recent wars, such as the Chechen Wars, the War in Georgia, the conflict in Ukraine, and the conflict in Syria. So, Russia has some experience fighting wars too. Did I mention nuclear weapons? Yeah, I did. Russia has thousands of them. They can come in the form of land-based ballistic missiles or submarine-based missiles. And some of them are ferocious, like the R-36M2 Voyevoda (SS-18 Mod 6) and the RSM-56 Buluva. That would pretty much ensure that if America, and the rest of NATO was stupid enough to do this, that both Russia and NATO would suffer lots of destruction and death. In other words, even if America had a chance to win, it would be offset by the sheer costs of such a war. And that’s ignoring the fact that Russia could bring its few allies into the war. If China decided to join the war, that would stretch America’s resources even more, lowering its chances of success even more. So, no, America would NOT be able to successfully invade Russia (at least, not without serious casualties).

response.answer_text: No. We lack most of the means that would be needed to even make a gesture at trying. So from a standing start, it wouldn’t be possible to even make a dent. We don’t have friends in Europe who would allow us to mass an invasion-sized force. We don’t have an invasion-sized force anywhere. We don’t have conscription, and we don’t have the political climate that would stand for conscription. But assume all those insuperable obstacles magically swept away. Now, by magic because it’s not happening in the real world, we have an army of millions, a navy with swarms of destroyers and assault landing craft, friends in Europe who will let us stage there and base there. We have huge factories cranking out munitions and all the stuff of war. Taxes are through the roof so we have money to fund it all. People are obedient and diligent and they work their ten hour days six days a week and go without everything but basic necessities so the surplus can be spent on our armed forces. Obesity is a distant memory. Our young men and women are fit and disciplined. Like magic. So what? Russia still has nukes. All that can be swept away in a couple of hours with a barrage of nukes. And if we pull the trigger on that invasion, it would be. Phoom.. and no more factories, cities, power plants, just shards and remnants. The whole thing is crazy within crazy piled upon crazy.

The last time somebody “successfully” invaded Russia — successfully in the sense that they were able to conquer it and administer it for a respectable period of time — was the Mongols in the Middle Ages. And Russia was a lot smaller then. And fragmented. Russia is not the highly organized behemoth some commentators describe. It is corrupt, it is often inept, and a lot of times, the right hand doesn’t know what the left is doing. Even in World War II, from which Russia emerged so gloriously triumphant, there was much disarray and ad-hoc nonsense well past the initial German invasion. Nor is it terribly populous; the US population is more than double that of Russia. The one insurmountable advantage Russia has is its sheer size. That, plus the deep continental climate that is unspeakably brutal, especially the further east one travels. Russia has got industrial centers and major cities scattered all over, including deep in Siberia, so if invaded, it can move its government and reestablish supply lines virtually beyond reach. (Siberia has never been the site of a major conventional war — I’m not counting the 16th century Russian conquest of the Khanate — and with good reason.)

America can invade Russia but the question is why. Also, would the invasion be successful? The answer to that is no. Well, maybe. For the sake of argument we could be successful. Lt’s say we secure the major population centers and the leadership of Russia has been captured. The question is what will the people in the countryside do? Will they lay down and comply or will they fight? If they feel oppressed by the government maybe the Russian people would welcome the US and hope for a better future. However, I believe the average Russian is similar to the average American. An outside invading force would be a uniter. As in, those people on the East Coast or West Coast may be messed up, but if those Russians try to take over we will fight together. In Russia it would be those Muscovites or Siberians may be jackasses but if the Americans try to take over we will fight together for our country. So, after subduing Moscow, St. Petersburg and Odense and Vladivostok the US would have an insurgency on its hands. The same goes if Russia were to invade the United States..

The simple answer is yes. The defined answer is yes and no. Why, well I will tel you. The US first of all has no reason to invade mainland russia. Second off the US would not want to annex or occupy russia. The US could easily invade through kamchakta during summer time and easily occupy it since there is virtually no russian miltary force there able to hold of an Invasion. Russia can't invade the US, it's just a fact. The US if invading through europe would most likely start in either poland or Ukraine, as too get as close to Moscow as possible. The front would purposely be small to limit troop spread. The US would also make a belign for Moscow to take control quickly. Russia would not be able to hold off US forces indefinitely. The US forces would know that if they stop for any more than 2-3 hours for rest that the Russians will be able to dig in deep. So US troops would be on double time and be moving every hour and every minute of every day. Russia would try and build defenses but would be stopped by quick moving US troops, and they would be forced to make their last stand at Moscow. Once there, the US would abandon all occupied land except for Moscow and roads and ports. With Moscow under control Russia will fall into disarray. The people will begin to rebel and riot, and the US will leave Russian troops to deal with it. This will force Russia to sign a peace treaty.

Anyone can invade anyone. Monaco can invade China, if it wanted to. All you have to do is to put troops inside the attacked country’s borders without an invitation, and it’s already fair to say that you have invaded them. The question is could this invasion be successful. And that depends on the point of the invasion. What is it for? Is it to gain land? To gain people? To get influence?The US can succeed in neither of those. US has a number of options: 1. Attack Russia from the East, where little military force is present, but at the same time there are almost no roads there and it's really far away from the population centers, you would have to go through the whole Siberia, and then across Urals to get to Moscow. This option can give the US access to resources: oil, gas, wood and so on, but I highly doubt they can hold it for long2. Attack Russia from the West, as did Napoleon and Hitler, meeting a monstrous amount of resistance, constant stabs in the back by the native population and the whole bulk of the Russian military. This invasion is a bit pointless in my opinion, as it gives the US no resources, a highly hostile population to control and a logistical nightmare that it has to overcome. All these options crumble after one word - “nukes". Russian nuclear doctrine permits use of nuclear weapons on an enemy, as a retaliation strike, or as weapon of last resort, when the survival of the state is at stake. As soon as US gets close to winning, it would get nuked with everything we have

In the literal meaning and intended meaning of the question, I do not think the US is able to invade Russia nor has any interest in expending resources (men and material/money) to invade Russia, without international support. With regards to the ability to invade Russia, the US would have to have an air and ground invasion requiring proximity to Russia. The NATO bases in Europe provide a platform to invade Russia, however the European countries have no reason to allow the US to use their bases for such an invasion. That pretty much leaves the US with only forces based in Alaska which is a long tank ride from Siberia to St Petersberg even if the US could get a foothold on the Pacific side. As for lack of intent to invade Russia, there is nothing to be gained by invading Russia. The US can buy Russian resources on the open market if they want which is cheaper than capturing them in a very expensive war. If Russia invaded the Baltic nations or other NATO members, then all bets are off and you would probably see a massive response from all of NATO with the US to liberate the NATO members and probably push into Russia to prevent that from ever happening again. What happens after that is really up to the Russian populace on whether they want to continue with their current Petrol-authoritarian regime or move to a modern, open, rule of law government.

No. For the sole reason that it will take too much resources even for the USA and China to invade Russia. Maybe the US army and navy can invade, but, like any other military power, they won’t stay here. Russian climate and poor infrastructure are a bitch even for Russians, let alone anyone else. Maybe it will be a decade-long siege, but without internal treason (which won’t have much success anyway, people here are pretty much anti-American even in aspects they shouldn’t be) it is impossible to grab hold of Russia reliably. Just one small example: Edmonton in Canada is on the latitude of Samara that is considered quite warm place by Russian standards, and during six months in a year it’s actually more comfortable than, say, Madrid (climate-wise). In Canada it’s the northernmost more or less big city. Moscow, 10th biggest city in the world, lies further to the north, let alone St. Petersburg that has as much population as the whole Finland. How many people live in Alaska? In Russia there are much more in much harsher conditions. Won’t click. And don’t forget about nukes.

I believe that if you own a nuclear weapon or any weapon of mass destruction, then you are a terrorist state- and of the most serious type. The definition of a terrorist is the person/entity who kills people not involved in a fight with him, and this applies clearly here- kill innocents to force others to capitulate. The excuses that they are needed to stop others from attacking you is so thin that it can’t cover any of this big sin. The only way you can prove you are sincere in this aim is to have a ‘continuous’ and ‘serious’ negotiations all the time with others to remove these weapons. The speaking about conducting a war with these weapons is even a much more magnified sin in my opinion. Does it then make sense to condemn Beshar for dropping chlorine on children and talk at the same time of a nuclear war. Talking of wars using mass destruction should be banned like banning talking to isis or into antisemitism and any other evil. The number of small wars in the world has unfortunately increased significantly due to the world being in an absolutely lawless state at the moment. The UN is hijacked by the security council, and it can be hijacked by any one of its members. People who like a peaceful world should come together and force these council members to either drop the right to Vito or better abolish the security council altogether. If it happened it would mark the first start of civilization in my opinion. If people are thinking right, this is in the interest of everyone in the world. It is shameful that we advanced in so many things, but we can’t put our house in order. With the help of digital technology(google for example!!), there is a real possibility to make a highly ordered, legal and happy world. All those who love themselves even if not the others, should rise up and help in achieving this. No one should ever think of condoling or even the thinking of going to a war using mass destruction/terrorist weapons. I would have thought that the US who is made from Russians, Chinese, Indians and a sample of every corner of the world would never think of attacking others with a weapon of mass destruction, because wherever you hit you will loose a relative. But then I remembered that the likelihood of a brother killing his own brother could be higher than killing a distant other. We are listening to our primitive inner selves and leaving aside all of what we learned.

Russia is very difficult for the invasion. It is too big for this. Napoleon in 1812 thought that when he enters Moscow he will gain control over Russia but found almost empty city instead. Can you imagine how many troops needed for control over such territory. And Russians won't just watch you to invade.  Before you get control over Siberia you will face thousands of nukes and around 50000000 soldiers. Plus do you know that almost every plant in Russia can be transformed in military factory in no time. Today it makes oil tomorrow it makes killing gas or bullets.  So today's tactics like shoot down military objects from planes, then make green zone and sit in it will not work in Russia. The USA will take several years and millions of soldiers to take Siberia from Russia. And don't forget about nukes.

This has probably been covered on Quora about 10 times already. During the 1950s, the US defense establishment attempted to determine if the United States could successfully win a war against the Soviet Union with an entirely successful pre-emptive nuclear strike. The base scenarios began before the USSR acquired nuclear weapons. The simple fact was even if the US delivered a massive nuclear bombardment on the facilities of the USSR, it expected that enough of the USSR would survive to mount a substantive defense to the US. There was no win scenario even with a nuclear advantage. Some things have changed, but a successful US invasion of the Federation does not face good odds. A Federation invasion of the US? Well, that wasn’t the question, and I don’t feel like thinking too much about 300,000 troops in Cuba, during the days of the October Crisis.

No, no country can successfully invade Russia. Russia is a successor of Russian Empire with more than 100 ethnicities included. Apart exciting diversity, that includes grudges and irreconcilable differences that are hundreds of years old. Russia guarantees peace by maintaining fragile equilibrium with political, economic and cultural means. Even though it disturbs peace occasionally in some places but it also guarantees it in other places. A hypothetical invader will mess up the status quo and will have to deal with it. And no invader would want that. Want to invade Russia? Be prepared to be an intermediary in the Armenia-Azerbaijan, Georgia-Ossetia, Ingushetia-Ossetia, Georgia-Abkhazia, Kirgiztan-Kazakhstan, etc. Add to the equation the relations with neighboring countries - Turkey, Iran, China, and Islamic fundamentalists who would not miss chance to establish a version of Khalifat in parts of the war-torn country. Unless one wants to have another former Yugoslavia but on much larger scale, extending to Europe and Asia, and with nukes, one will think twice before even considering an invasion. It is not only a privilege to be Russia but also a difficult job not many people would enjoy doing.

No,why would the U.S. want to invade Russia? And Russia is a huge country in land mass, where would one start such an invasion and what would be the goal? The Germans tried in WW II and failed. Perhaps the outcome of the German invasion of Russia would have been different had Hitler not declared war on the U.S. after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, December 7, 1941. After that, Hitler had two fronts one in the West and one in the East. Some of his resources in the East had to be used to fight the growing power of the West. Some say, German troops where in the suburbs of Moscow, however, even if the Germans had captured Moscow, it would have been a more symbolic victory than a strategic one.

The US alone couldn’t do it. It will need help from NATO. It's almost certain that Western European countries like France and England would join, the same thing couldn't be said for the Eastern European countries, for fear of a Russian invasion. So as a result the Russians will think the most likely invasion spot would be in Scandinavia. However in reality it's across the Bering strait into Siberia. Since Russia has no way of invading the western European countries directly, it would be forced to move east to Siberia, but they wouldn't get there until a large chunk of land has been occupied by US forces. Now the western European forces would take a chance and attack through Scandinavia. At this point the Russians would likely ask for an armistice. So yes and no, the US would be able to land and hold a beachhead, and maybe push some miles in but not enough to completely occupy it.

Well, it does have the ability but so did Napoleon (It only cost him a Grande Armee) and Hitler (more expensive, much more expensive) but why on Earth would they want to? Military invasions are hugely expensive things especially when you lose. For America to invade Russia would be a case of spending huge sums of money equipment and lives for little if any gain. Monaco invading China? Actually its the other way around. Not the People's Liberation Army but China's billionaires who regularly hit Monacos casinos, they may or may not watch the Grand Prix, buy some expensive stuff like Gucci and then return home. The plus side is that no one dies.

Not unless some technology would to be invented to neutralize nukes. Russian has thousand of nukes, invading Russia means committing suicide. Hypothetically, if that technology was invented, nukes are now neutralized. Could US successfully invade Russia? My answer is yes: Attack from the east, not west. Use Japan as staging.NATO to form defense line 1 along Russian border, defense line 2 behind former eastern block countries.Seduce Russia to move their main force east.Invite the Chinese in as cannon fodder.Fight along trans Siberia railway and use that as logistic support route.By the time, we pass Ural, Russia is about done.

Of course we could. With our military capabilities, that would be easy. The fact of the matter is, we have zero reason to invade Russia. We have no interest in invading Russia, and we never did. If we ever DID have any interest, we would have been occupying Russia decades ago. Our heavy military presence in the area of the Black Sea is a total charade— a farce which we carry out to make our so called ally, Turkey, feel confident that Russia would not attack THEM. We have about as good a reason to invade Russia as we have to invade Denmark. Most people in The United States take a very dim view of individuals who are in favor of invading another country.

Define “success.” Generally speaking, no. If you’re talking about invading, conquering, and holding Russia, it’s far too big. The USA does not have the troops to do it. The USA could almost certainly invade and occupy something small like the Crimean Peninsula, but could not hold it indefinitely, and not without great cost in money and blood.

response.answer_text: Yes. How would they accomplish this? Host an international military grade battle drone contest in South Korea with different levels. The lowest level getting a million dollar prize, and the highest level getting a multibillion dollar military contract. Once everyone shows up with hundreds of thousands of military grade drones the U.S. military confiscates them and send them all to Russia. More realistic scenario, send in several special ops units in undetectable aircraft to the heart of Russia. Assassinate top officials, and hold moderate level officials hostage. A massive land invasion is illogical, and unlikely to succeed, but if anybody can do it the U.S. can. I mean they have apache helicopters…

We DID invade the Soviet Union in 1919, albeit not “successfully.” President Woodrow Wilson sent the American Expeditionary Force (left over from WWI but major remnants still in Europe) into Russia to overthrow the Russian Revolution. Memories of this are why the Soviet Union—and Putin now—don’t trust the United States. This fact isn’t taught in our schools, but it is readily available in any university library.

In a word, No. Russia is the only country with nuclear strategic parity to the US, so that rules out any such confrontation. Conventional war? Hitler attacked with the largest invasion force ever assembled. The Soviet response was overwhelming and turned the tide in less than 2 years. A dictatorship ruling on fear and terror could not mobilize sufficient manpower to overcome the Russian Bear, so how could a democracy that is already weary of prolonged engagements in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Invading Russia and winning that fight arectwo very different things. Just as in the old board game of RISK, anybody can invade anybody, but unless the dice are very favorable winning becomes a non trivia thing. In both WWI and WWII. Germany invaded Russia (USSR). In WWI, it was a huge drag on the German nation to the point that they retrieved Lenin from exile and shipped him home to disrupt the country, which he did, and which the German cane to regret! In WWII, it could logically be argued that Barbarossa was the beginning of the end for Nazi germany even though the pushed to the gates of Moscow! Could the US invade Russia (or vice versa)? Of course, but the act of invading would be about the dumbest thing either nation could do!
Surely it can. Would the invasion be successful is another question and it was discussed many times here on Quora. Mind that no invasion into Russia ended good for the invading force.

the key thing is nuclear weapon. conventional weaponry could be outnumbered and suppressed from the air. but you can't suppress nukes until you possess some SF-like superior weapon. you can’t disable it with computer virus obviously. and even then, after taking control of some part of the country (i’d suggest heavy populated and climate-friendly territory east of Ural mountains), US will face heavy guerilla resistance. let along negative attitude towards invaders, Russians are heavy patriotic and fed with anti-western propaganda over 1917–1990 and from 2008 onwards. and the only possible reason to do that (in assumption one has a weapon to disable nukes) i could think of is a direct threat to the US territories from Russia. even the aggression towards NATO countries won’t be enough.

Soviet strength is considerable and both countries have nuclear weapons, so the infrastructure to produce weapons could be curtailed if there was the inclination to invade. It would be foolish to think the defending country, in this instance, would not use such weapons. On the other hand, we have never been invaded for one simple fact. There isn't a country on earth so well equipped with small arms and enough ammunition to defend itself, just relying on the population.

Can? As in physically put troops on the ground in Russia proper? Sure, we could even keep them resupplied and keep them there indefinitely if we wanted… as long as Russia doesnt actually respond. Of course in the REAL world, the Russians would not take too kindly to such an operation, and would react accordingly…and this would not be a fight we would win, and they'd quickly reclaim whatever beachhead we had took.

Throughout history, several countries have attempted to invade Russia and failed. The most recent were the Germans in WW 2. Before that was Napoleon and the French. An attempt was made by Charles II and the Swedes. All three were defeated by the Russians. The sole winner were the Mongols in the 12th century and a couple cities in Russian territory were taken by the Vikings in the 10th century. While the U.S. stands a bette chance in current time, invasion would exact a heavy price Holding the territory for a length of time would be impossible.

Yes. But not in the modern sense where the USA wins a war and takes the whole place over. To take over a landmass the size of Russia would take generations. Think 100 Years War level of long. The US would attack, and annex a part in exchange for temporary peace. Then attack again and get another chunk. Then consolidate. Meanwhile the Russian state gradually weakens allowing the US to attack and take yet more in a Land for Peace deal reminiscent of what the Arabs are trying to pull on Israel. Then once enough ethnic Russians are living in the newer states of the USA, the rest will just say F* it and join the USA to escape the misery that the US puts them in. The best parts of Russia are very close to Eastern Europe so the loss of those provinces would make the rest of Russia very hard pressed.

Technically even Luxemburg and Monako can invade Russia (without any impressive result, I suppose, but still…) Is it probable? I doubt it. But… These days we're not always speaking about “conventional invasion”, and a big part of this are Russian hybrid wars lately. You can invade a country with hackers. You can have a trade war. You can fight somebody with propaganda of is strong enough, etc.. Could USA fall to those methods? Maybe, why not? You should at least learn all modern methods of war to be a superpower, I suppose.

We are known for poor management of our own country -Russia, but viciously defending it against all enemies through centuries. Plus enormous pile of nuclear and conventional weapons and a large Army with civilian population conditioned by anti-West propaganda and ready for sacrifice. And what might be the US reason to invade Russia? The US does not really need our gas and oil, we are NOT nice people since nobody likes Russians and the climate is awful. Come and try to live in Russia for a few months then you will abandon all ideas of invading Russia!

Yes, Hold it for any length of time is a different thing. Actually since large parts of Russia are uninhabited, maybe holding it is possible. All the people that talk about Russia’s size, yes. But go and look at the population centers. Russia is extremely rugged, they are giving away land to people that will actually live on it for multiple years.

Not at all. Because its military power is really so powerful in various fields. particularly its defensive system is stronger than the US based on my perspective. And also its geographical location is better than the US (for fighting and particularly for defending) and it make that hard for the US to fight Russia. Besides Russa’s largeness is as big as a convenient which can be a difficulty for USA how to fight it!

No, not successfully. Russia is a HUGE country and can call up millions of people if needed. Both Napoleon and Hitler failed in their invasions of the country. Additionally, Russia has nuclear weapons, and most likely would use them if it came to that.

Sure. It can. The problem is that even if take nuclear weapons out of the equation it would still take millions of lives on both sides and probably trillions of dollars. It would make the Vietnam War look like a walk in the park. The victor of such clash (if the world as we know wasn’t destroyed) would be China.

He can but it will start a war. RUSSIA has the largest stock piles of nuclear weapons. On top of that their military is number 2 in the world. The Russian military is in the middle East to Africa. They have top air Force with too of the line air Force. Lol TOTAL SUICIDE
“The secret of politics? Make a peace with Russia “ Otto von Bismarck Thankfully, so far America prefers invide much weaker opponents and not to fight with equals.

NATO conventional forces out number the Russian military but Russia has a nuclear "Trump suite" to play! Russia would threaten to nuke any country that allows an attack to be launched from their soil! Those few countries left can be promptly nuked day one! Wars over and the US would be kicked out of Europe ! That's why Russia will never give up their nukes.
No, there is far too much territory to cover. Any army invading Russia would be crushed if not by modern conventional weapons then by nuclear weapons.
The US couldn’t even succeed in Iraq, much less in much larger Afghanistan. Napoleon and Hitler speak to the near-impossibility of controlling Russia. No, the paper tiger would shred.
In 1941, Hitler’s edge was much greater than America’s edge today, yet that invasion still failed. Same thing with Napoleon in 1812.

No. Russia is too large of an area to secure. They are also a nuclear power. Russia borders several countries that are enemies with the US. Mongolia is the only nation that successfully occupied Russia.

Of course we could but what you can do and what you should do are two very different things. We’d be damn sorry at the very least. They’d lob nukes at strategic targets over here and at our allies you can be sure of that. It would basically be the end of our way of life and world stability (such as it is).

No, because of the nukes. But the Russian army is not the equal of the US army, and it makes no sense to talk of it overrunning Western Europe. Russian military equipment doesn’t have a great recent history versus Western equipment.
Not at all, because Russia is a powerful country with a great geopolitical …
Not at all. Russia is also a super power. This will lead to WWIII. Not sure you know Putin is almost controlling EU and ME. Russia biggest alliances is China.
If no one touched the nukes maybe, but it would be a long and bloody war. It would also be greatly helpful if our nato allies assisted us
i will call this invasion The Greatest Military Blunder. None of all will go close to the situation called success. There shall only distruction.
Without considering nuclear option US can defeat Russia in any event. Even US “naval” air force can defeat Russian Air force. But defeating is onething, invading is another.
Yes. Germany successfully invaded Russia as have others. What happened to them in Russia after their invasion didn’t work out so well for them.
Our Pentagon generals have recently said that our military today can not currently even beat Russia in a land war—much less try to invade Russia and do it—
Russia is behind most western countries in almost every measure that counts. No offense to Russians, but why in the world would the US want to that?
Nope. Just ask: Charles XII of SwedenNapoleon BonaparteAdolf Hitler
No
